perturbation.original_text: Within fifteen (15) days after the end of each calendar month that occurs during the remainder of the Term of the Agreement, subject to Paragraph 10.01(e), FCE will calculate and invoice ExxonMobil for the actual amounts incurred (for charges permitted in accordance with the respective Project Description(s)) during the immediately preceding calendar month.
perturbation.changed_text: Within forty-five (45) days after the end of each calendar month that occurs during the remainder of the Term of the Agreement, subject to Paragraph 10.01(e), FCE will calculate and invoice ExxonMobil for the actual amounts incurred (for charges permitted in accordance with the respective Project Description(s)) during the immediately preceding calendar month.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the invoicing period to 45 days, potentially conflicting with standard business practices and prompt payment laws that favor shorter invoicing cycles. Many jurisdictions imply a 'reasonable time' for invoicing, and 45 days could be considered unreasonable, especially if it deviates significantly from industry norms or prior dealings between the parties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Implied Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing; potential violation of state-specific prompt payment laws.

perturbation.original_text: Except as otherwise specifically provided herein, ExxonMobil agrees to pay FCE the amount of each invoice under this Agreement within thirty (30) days following ExxonMobil's receipt. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if ExxonMobil has a good faith dispute regarding any amounts invoiced by FCE, ExxonMobil may withhold payment for the disputed amount, provided that ExxonMobil pays the undisputed amount and notifies FCE in writing of the specific amount and nature of the dispute promptly upon receipt of FCE's invoice in which case the Parties shall attempt to resolve the dispute in good faith. The Parties shall endeavor to resolve such dispute within fifteen (15) days of notice of the dispute, and ExxonMobil shall remit payment to FCE within fifteen (15) days of resolution of such dispute.
perturbation.changed_text: Except as otherwise specifically provided herein, ExxonMobil agrees to pay FCE the amount of each invoice under this Agreement within ninety (90) days following ExxonMobil's receipt. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if ExxonMobil has a good faith dispute regarding any amounts invoiced by FCE, ExxonMobil may withhold payment for the disputed amount, provided that ExxonMobil pays the undisputed amount and notifies FCE in writing of the specific amount and nature of the dispute promptly upon receipt of FCE's invoice in which case the Parties shall attempt to resolve the dispute in good faith. The Parties shall endeavor to resolve such dispute within forty-five (45) days of notice of the dispute, and ExxonMobil shall remit payment to FCE within forty-five (45) days of resolution of such dispute.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the payment period to 90 days and dispute resolution to 45 days which may contradict state laws that mandate shorter payment terms, especially for small businesses. Such extended periods might be deemed unreasonable and could violate the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, particularly if the industry standard or prior dealings suggest a shorter timeframe.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of state prompt payment laws; breach of implied duty of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: Such notice, demand, request, or other communications will be deemed to have been sufficiently given by and will be effective upon the earliest of: (a) delivering the same to a reputable courier service that requires a signature upon delivery; (b) mailing the same by registered or certified first-class mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested; (c) if an e-mail is provided, then by e-mail with receipt confirmation followed by mailing the same or (d) actual receipt by the addressee.
perturbation.changed_text: Such notice, demand, request, or other communications will be deemed to have been sufficiently given by and will be effective upon the latest of: (a) delivering the same to a reputable courier service that requires a signature upon delivery; (b) mailing the same by registered or certified first-class mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested; (c) if an e-mail is provided, then by e-mail with receipt confirmation followed by mailing the same or (d) actual receipt by the addressee.
perturbation.explanation: Switching 'earliest' to 'latest' would cause a major delay. The notice would be effective once all the conditions listed are satisfied. Thus, it will be difficult to send the notice as any one of the conditions might cause a delay. This is contradictory to the concept of notice in general.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
